questiontext.text:
Non-unique solutions

The key to obtaining a unique solution of the system \(AX=B\) is to find \(A^{-1}\). What happens when \(A^{-1}\) does not exist?

Consider the system \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 5 & \qquad(1) \\ 4x_1& + & 6x_2 & = & 10 & \qquad (2) \\ \end{matrix}\] In matrix form this becomes \[\left[\begin{matrix} 2&3\\ 4&6\end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix} x_1\\ x_2\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix} 5\\ 10\end{matrix}\right].\]

Example

Identify the matrix \(A\) and hence find \(A^{-1}\) if it exists.

Solution

\[A=\left[\begin{matrix} 2 & 3\\ 4 & 6 \end{matrix}\right]\] and \(|A|=2\times 6-4 \times 3=0.\) Hence \(A^{-1}\) does not exist.

Looking at the original system we see that Equation (2) is simply Equation (1) with all coefficients doubled. In effect we have only one equation for the two unknowns \(x_1\) and \(x_2\). The equations are consistent and have infinitely many solutions.

If we let \(x_2\) assume a particular value, \(t\) say, then \(x_1\) must take the value \(x_1=\dfrac{1}{2}(5-3t)\), i.e., the solution to the given equations is:

\[x_2=t,\qquad x_1=\dfrac{1}{2}(5-3t)\] where \(t\) is called a parameter.

For each value of \(t\) there are unique values for \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) which satisfy the original system of equations. For example, if \(t=1\), then \(x_2=1\), \(x_1=1\), if \(t=-3\) then \(x_2=-3\), \(x_1=7\) and so on.

We can think of the initial problem as finding a point of intersection of the lines given by the equations. Equation (2) is simply equation (1) multiplied by \(2\) and describes the same line. Every point on the line is a point of intersection.


Now consider the system \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 5 & \qquad (3) \\ 4x_1 & + & 6x_2 & = & 9 & \qquad (4)\\ \end{matrix}\] Since the left-hand sides are the same as those in the previous system then \(A\) is the same and again \(A^{-1}\) does not exist. There is no solution to the Equations (3) and (4).

Indeed, if we double Equation (3) we obtain \[4x_1+6x_2=10\] which conflicts with Equation (4). There are thus no solutions to (3) and (4) and the equations are said to be inconsistent.

Thinking of the geometry, the problem is now to find the intersection of two different but parallel lines. Of course such parallel lines will never meet so there are no points of intersection.
